So, we trudged down to the front desk to request a room off of Bourbon. Like another reviewer experienced, we were told to try a new room that was off Bourbon, but when we got to the new room, it was still on Bourbon. The front desk outright lied. My guess is that they only give you rooms off of Bourbon if you REALLY complain a lot. Anyway, the room they gave us was on the 7th floor and this worked perfectly. No problem with noise if you are above the 5th floor or so. Saturday night a street band played loudly until about 11PM, but that was it. The rest of the stay was as quiet as could be within the room. Great room, excellent beds! Very friendly staff overall.....except for the front desk. It seems like the front desk staff are trained to be non-compliant with an attitude. Take home message: Get what you want and don't worry about offending them. Do what you have to do and treat them exactly the way they treat you; that is, with no respect whatsoever. When I go back to this hotel (and I will), I will take great pleasure in making the front desk staff miserable every chance I get. They deserve it. OK, so anyway, great stay overall. Would definitely go back. Excellent location and lots of sleep when we wanted it!

Reviews.Title: “Breakfast to die for”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Great resturant, wonderful rooms, and nice location. Stayed their three night with two other couples from California. I should mention the price it was unbelievable 89.00 per night. on -----. They have a nice lounge on the 4 th floor. The service was very good not quite excellent but close. We will try to stay here next year before our cruise.

Reviews.Title: “Astor Crowne Plaza #1 in New Orleans”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and I go to New Orleans 3 or 4 times a year and we've found that The Astor is the best hotel in the city for location, ameneties and value. It is generally priced about $100 less per night than say, the Fairmont, La Pavillion, Monteleone or Omni. The hotel is surprisingly quiet given it's French Quarter location, but just in case, request a room away from Bourbon and Canal. The Bourbon St entrance puts you directly across the street from the fabled Storeyville Lounge, where you can hear Nawlin's Queen of the Blues, Marva Wright every Thursday. The Acme Oyster House is located near the Hotel's back entrance. The St Charles street car stops directly across Canal from the Astor and you can cimb aboard for magical stops along the mossy tree shaded streets of the Garden District, such as Commander's Palace, Audabon Park and Magazine St. We found the Concierge to be invaluable, the staff very accomadating and The Astor's extensive amenities will satisfy even discriminaging travelers.

Reviews.Title: “Not your typical city”
Reviews.Author: tute
Reviews.Content: The Crowne Plaza is very convenient at the edge of the French Quarter and right on the Canal and St. Charles Streetcar Lines. We stayed on the 7th floor in mid January and we could hear the bass from the bands and whooping until 4am during the weeknights even up that high, so i can't imagine how loud it must be in the French Quarter. They give you a bag of earplugs and a blindfold on your beds. I was a little disappointed that the rooms were not as nice as the Crowne Plaza I stayed in San Francisco (which had free internet connection unlike this one) and they are smallish. I made the mistake of walking barefoot to get some ice and the hall carpets feel like they haven't been cleaned for years. This may not be their fault but a fact of New Orleans. The streets reek of sour beer even though the store owners hose the sidewalks down regularly. It looks like one of the previous guests had spilled a maragarita on a corner of the room carpet because it was still a little sticky and stained red. The rooms were a good value ( I paid $90/ night through easyclicktravel) but I probably would pick a hotel a little farther down Canal street toward the Convention center and away from the Bourbon street noise. Walking back to our hotel at night past the strip clubs and the drunks was a little scary.

Reviews.Title: “Only Place to Stay!”
Reviews.Author: rkochman
Reviews.Content: Ignore the clown who gave this hotel a bad review because of parking. If you talk nice, they'll get your car for you. This place is the ONLY place to stay if you want to hang out in the French Quarter. Everything is in easy walking distance unless you're infirmed. Not noisy like the small hotels that are in the middle of the Quarter, this place is quiet, clean and has a great staff. We never used our car the whole time we were there and we went to the Riverwalk, Harrah's, NOLA Restaurant, Pat O'Brien's, Brennan's, etc. all by foot and easy walking. If you stay anywhere else and then see this place and where it's located, you will kick yourself in the butt!

Reviews.Title: “Best value and accomodations!”
Reviews.Author: szpal
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Astor between the 27th of December and the 5th of January and had a great experience. Here's a critique of our stay: LOCATION: If it's possible to be at the edge of the quarter and in the heart of it at the same time, then that describes the Astor. One door goes out to Bourbon and the other to Canal St. It's great if you want to experience the quarter, but want to leave it and look at other sites as well. This is the perfect hotel if you're NOT driving. We never even needed our car. The Canal St. cable car and the Garden District car both stop right across the street from the hotel. ROOMS: The rooms were exceptionally clean and very comfortable. The "sleep amenities" are wonderful. They include super pillows, room blackening drapes, eye masks, and some sort of sleep CD but we never saw that while we were there. We were on the 9th floor, away from Bourbon, and even on New Year's Eve it was quiet. The hotel was full during that time for the Sugar Bowl, but it was still really quiet. Loved that! Room had great lamps too, if you like to read. HOUSEKEEPING: Rooms were clean (and I'm a germ freak so that says something). I also loved that the duvet covers were pristine white, so you KNEW that they'd been freshly washed before you got there. It made the whole room feel clean. Housekeeping staff were wonderful--everyone spoke to us and made us feel welcome. Wish I could say the same for the.... FRONT DESK: Sadly, this wasn't the highest point of our stay. From check-in on, the front desk staff just wasn't very friendly or helpful. We dealt with them daily on various things and they acted like we were inconveniencing them every time. No smiles, no "Good Morning," nothing. It's too bad because I've always felt like the front desk sets the tone for the whole stay. The management seemed great---maybe it's hard to find good help there. Note to the Astor: let your housekeeping department come in and train the front desk on how to make your guests feel #1. RATE: This is the best part. The value was unbelievable. We paid $119 a night for every night but the 30th and 31st (those were around $249). Even when they were full during the Sugar Bowl, our rate didn't go up. In my opinion, this is the BEST located hotel in the quarter, and the rate is better than any other hotel we checked. By the way, we stayed with our 8 and 10 year old, used room service, and found that to be a great value, too. DON'T MISS: There are so many things to see and do, but here are my favorites. THE PRALINE CONNECTION GOSPEL BRUNCH--wow is all I can say. These women can SING! My kids (who thought they were going to be bored) had a great time and got invited up on stage which was the highlight of their trip. DICKIE BRENNAN'S STEAK HOUSE: Best meal I've ever had and right around the corner from the Astor. HAUNTED HISTORY GHOST TOUR: Great way to "sneak" some history lessons on your kids. SWAMP TOUR: Didn't really want to do this one, but it ended up being a great day--even with no gators to be seen. Have a great time in N'Awlins!

Reviews.Title: “Quiet Room at the Astor”
Reviews.Author: Makeithappen57
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Astor Crowne Plaza for four nights between Christmas and New Years. Check in was smooth and as they didn't have our requested King Room we were placed on the fourth floor where we would receive complimentary breakfast and snacks at dinner time. Breakfast was a choice of cold cereal, juice, coffee/tea, various rolls and yogurt. Evening snacks included two hot appetizer meats and you could purchase beer or wine. Our room on this floor had a view of a parking garage where honking cars lived. I say honking cars tongue in cheek because it seemed the rule there was to honk while driving up or down in the garage to alert other drivers you were coming. It wasn't a huge issue to us, but next visit we will request a view of the city. Otherwise the room was very quiet with a nice bed. We'd stay here again due to the great proximity to the French Quarter (right on the corner of Bourbon and Canal), close enough to Bourbon St. without all the noise. We did a couple things while in NOLA that I'd like to suggest you try. Chef Joe Faroldi has a cooking class called the Louisiana Heritage Cafe School of Cooking (------------------------ ) in the Beinville House Hotel. Chef Joe has lived his entire life in the French Quarter and peppers his class with stories of those days and wonderful cooking suggestions. If you go make sure you're hungry as his cooking class helpings are huge. The menu on our trip included Seafood Beignets, mixed green garden salad with creole honey mustard dressing, Cajun Jambalaya and a delicious Bread Pudding with Bananas Foster Sauce topping (his creation). Yum! We read about Chef Joe in the local advertising book in our room. Commanders Palace is not to be missed, make your reservations before you go as they fill up early. We had the lunch special-absolutely excellent. The bread pudding souffle is superb, and will ruin your taste buds for any other bread pudding. We also ate at Emeril's Delmonico resturant the last night of our stay. I wish we'd eaten there the first night as we agree we'd have enjoyed it more (too much rich food all week). The food was well prepared and the servers were knowledgable and efficient. Mr. B's Bistro is not a place we'll return to. Crowded, the drinks are so-so, and the food is the same. I had the barbequed shrimp which is a messy meal, heads on the shrimp and to me tasted like dirt. Their bread pudding was dry, not to be recommended. Hopes this review helps you in deciding what to do if you visit NOLA. Jill Miller Cincinnati, OH

Reviews.Title: “No complaints at all !!!”
Reviews.Author: FerFer94
Reviews.Content: My husband & I along with another couple we know were in New Orleans Dec 9 -12 & stayed at the Astor Crowne Plaza... It was fabulous & nobody had any complaints.... The location was real convenient to frequent Bourbon Street. About a half block from the hotel. The trolleys to explore certain parts of the city were right across the street. The rooms were very nice & spacious. The bedding felt like you were sleeping on cotton with the down comforter & other accessories. The staff was friendly & assisted with any requests or questions we had... We didn't try any of the food at the hotel but there are many great restaurants in walking distance... Ralph & Kakoo's (not sure if that's spelled right) was great as well as this restaurant called Mother's... A car wasn't really needed at this hotel given the location... Most places were within walking distance & the trolley is on the same street as the hotel if it wasn't within walking distance... We only used the car once to go to a mall in Kenner to do some Christmas shopping & it was pretty quick to get the shuttle to go to the garage... We would definitely stay here again....

Reviews.Title: “No Problems with the Astor Crowne Plaza!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My girlfriend and I just got back from a weekend in New Orleans and stayed at The Astor Crowne. We had reservations for one night (Friday), but decided to stay an extra night. As many of the reviews have said, the best thing about the Astor is the location. Located on the corner of Bourbon and Canal, the hotel is located near everything. I was pleased with the hotel. We were there about a week before Christmas and the lobby was decorated beautifully. Our room was just that, a room. Nothing really to write home about, but it was very clean and spacious. I found the bed to be very comfortable. We were on the 8th floor with a pretty decent view of Canal St. I believe the hotel is 14 stories. The Astor also has a work-out room and pool/jacuzzi on the 3rd floor. The work-out room seemed nice enough (although a bit small), and the pool/jacuzzi on the deck would be nice for warm weather. Downstairs in the lobby is a decent sized bar with a flat screen tv built into the wall. I had a beer and watched the football game for about an hour in this area. It was a nice area to relax and just chill in. The bar is a bit pricey. I believed I paid $4.25 for an Abita Beer on draft. But whatever, it's a hotel bar, so of course it's going to be a little on the expensive side. There is also a restaraunt attached to the hotel (right off the bar), that we did not at eat at. The restaraunt also serves breakfast in the morning. They had a Continental breakfast for $9.99 or you could get everything on the Continental plus eggs and a few other itmes for somewhere in the $13.00 range. For what you got, it seemed a bit pricey to me. There's a place called Mena's that serves breakfast, and is located only a few blocks (walking distance) from the hotel which I would recommend. Super cheap and the food was good. If you drive in (and valet park), make sure you get everything out of your car that you need, as the parking garage is 10 blocks away. The valet's exact words to me were "Make sure you get everything out of your car cause your vehicle is going in a parking garage 10 blocks away." When we left, a shuttle bus took us and others to the parking garage. A bit of a hassle, but no to big of a deal. We paid $22 a day to park. Not cheap, but it beats driving around New Orleans looking for a place to park on the street. I didn't have much dealings with the staff, so I can't really comment on them. All-in-all this was a very nice hotel that I would stay at again without hesitation! We paid $99 a night, which to me, seems like a really good deal for the location.

Reviews.Title: “Avoid this hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We visit New Orleans frequently and have stayed at a wide range of hotels in the downtown area. The Astor Crowne Plaza is clearly the worst experience we've ever had in New Orleans. First, there were continuing problems with the electronic door lock throughout our six day stay. Even though we had the key reprogrammed at least once a day, it was not until the fifth day when the front desk said they'd send a maintenance person "right away". They showed up over an hour later (one guy working and three watching) and after spending an hour on the door, it was no better than before. Second, the parking situation is extremely inconvenient, requiring you to ride a shuttle to a scary place near the projects. The total time to the car was frequently 20-30 minutes. Finally, the food was nondescript at best and my New Orleans-born wife had the worst milk punch of her life. Overall, there are far better choices in downtown New Orleans

Reviews.Title: “New Oleans at it's best!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: we stayed here 4 days and couldn't have been more pleased!!!friendly helpful staff!! nice clean Hotel close to Everything in the french quarter!!!

Reviews.Title: “Exactly what I expected + more”
Reviews.Author: FredLambo
Reviews.Content: Date of Reservation: September 10, 2004 A few things about me: 30-something, self-employed professional male. My Criteria: 3+ to 4 star hotel, clean and reasonably priced, close to downtown (French Quarter) After reading quite a few (hotel) reviews in Trip Advisor, I felt a little uneasy about booking anything in New Orleans (A recent jaunt to Orlando left me underwhelmed about tourist towns). My past experience with the Crowne Plaza (Windsor, Ontario and Montreal Quebec) helped in my decision. I am happy to say that the other reviews for the Crowne were accurate (except for the â€˜just okâ€™ review â€“ they must be used to 5-star hotels) and I received exactly what I expected: a clean, quiet room, with a nice view (my particular room gave the long view of Bourbon street) and reasonably priced ($148). All of the staff was very pleasant and they always had a friendly greeting for me. (Yes, ALL) I did not drive, so I cannot comment on parking, but I think valet is 30/night or there are self-parking lots close by (10/night). I did notice that the drop-off zone is quite small due to the hotels location, but my driver had no problem picking me up. Also, I cannot comment on room service (did not order), but there were plenty of very nice restaurants close by that I was quite content with. The casino is a short walk (5-10 minutes) if you are the gambling type, but I would recommend a cab (not to put a scare into any one, I walk everywhere, but I always stay with the crowds and away from dark alleys). Bottom line: I will return to New Orleans and more than likely, unless Iâ€™m feeling a bit adventurous (Hotel Monaco was my second choice based on Trip Advisor reviews), I will stay at the Crowne. (btw, I kept my email secret to avoid spam, but other wise I would be open to offer some more tips on New Orleans).

Reviews.Title: “Highly Recommended”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I highly recommend this hotel. It's right on the entrance of the French Quarter. Our room is surprisingly quiet, and very clean and comfortable. Lot of very good restaurants nearby. Acme Oyster House is favorite of mine if you love oysters, poboys, crawfish at very reasonable prices. Across the street is St Charles street car which can take you around town including garden district and CBD. Would definitely stay here again

Reviews.Title: “Exactly what we wanted”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed in December of 2003 and the hotel was exactly what I wanted. Easy check-in (and there was a crowd of people for a football thing going on, but they moved them along quickly). Our room had a great view right down Bourbon street. Nice and large room, nice water pressure. I remember the elevator being not so close, but other than that, the geography was perfect. It's also nice because it's right at the start of bourbon street so you can walk down that way if you want, or take the streetcar down to explore the rest of the city. The staff was friendly, our room was cleaned well once per day, and no one was knocking on our door to clean the room when we had a DND sign up. My girlfriend and I loved it. It was especially nice the night after a bit of over-drinking... the room is nice and comfortable for those feeling a bit naseous. Check out was easy... I had a cell phone so I didn't make any calls, but I bet the cost was a lot. The only negative thing was there wasn't a cheaper restaurant in the hotel to just grab a quick bite - but plenty of stuff that was local. Quick tip, avoid Arnaud's and the other expensive places on Bourbon street. The food is pricey and you can get much better the further out of the city you go. We paid a pretty cheap rate too - something like $80 per night which was unbelieveable... but i guess New Orleans in the winter isn't peak tourist time. Oh, one more think, check out the dueling piano players!

Reviews.Title: “Great Location and Hotel”
Reviews.Author: keiardi
Reviews.Content: This hotel was fantastic! The rooms were very clean, beds oh so comfy, and it's in a great location if you want to be near the action of Bourbon Street. We had a 9th floor room. We couldn't see Bourbon Street, but we could hear it. (Not too bad though.) I'm sure it is noisy on the lower floors. Check in/check out was very fast and smooth. We arrived at 11:00 AM and got right into our room. The concierge was very helpful also. Eateries - The Gumbo Shop was very good and not terribley expensive. The French Market Cafe was OK. You pay for the atmosphere there because it is an open air cafe. We had a bad experience at the Court of Two Sisters; found a large piece of glass in the artichoke salad. The Cheesecake Bistro on St. Charles Ave. is very good and not as expensive as the French Quarter restaurants. Pat O'Brien's in the Jackson Brewery is also very nice. Great view of the river! Email me if you have any specific questions.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent! Will stay here again and again!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The Astor Crowne Plaza is a wonderful hotel! Check-in and check-out was quick and easy, the room was HUGE, beds were oh so comfy and the employees were very nice and helpful. It's location is perfect...right on the corner of Bourbon and Canal. The street car runs right in front of the hotel on Canal, so you can ride to the Riverwalk, French Market, etc. as opposed to walking or taking a cab. We travel to New Orleans frequently and we will definitely stay here again and again.

Reviews.Title: “Just OK”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The hotel was OK, nothing spectacular, although the location is prime. Stayed here w/ my husband during a conference at the end of April 2004. (Would have preferred to stay at the Marriott just a few steps next door, but they were already booked and their price was slightly higher). Our hotel room had some sort of leak which made the carpeting near our bed soaking wet the 2nd night we stayed there. We informed the front desk who sent someone up later that day, but we were told it couldn't be fixed during the remainder of our stay. We thought management would have at least offered to move us to another room, but they didn't. Also, I was trying to mail a package during our stay there. I asked about 3 different staff people for directions to the Post Office, and believe it or not, none of them were sure exactly where it was! They gave me 3 different locations/directions, and I never did find it. Finally, I asked another person at the front desk, who then told me that they could mail it out for me from the hotel. So I left the package, which contained highly important information and a check, with the front desk representative. 2 months later, the package still HAS NOT been delivered to the recipient! Quite appalling. I called the hotel and they could not locate the package. I was told that mail wasn't the most reliable in the New Orleans area (be aware). Needless to say, I had to put a "stop-payment" on the check, but the hotel didn't offer to compensate me on anything. I highly doubt we would ever stay in this hotel again, nor would we recommend it to any of our friends or family.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I was a little apprehensive about making a reservation at a hotel that I didn't get a recommendation. All my fears quickly went away when we walked through the front door. Excellent location, excellant staff.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, great service, great value”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We had a large group visit the French Quarter for Easter and all stayed at the Astor. The rooms were spacious, clean and comfortable. Housekeeping was immaculate and friendly (although some of our rooms weren't made until dinnertime.) The hotel is in a great location - within walking distance of everything: bars, restaurants, shops and more bars. A side note: we found a great little bar/restaurant across from Margaritaville called Coops - great food at very reasonable prices and the atmosphere is fun, comfortable. Great experience all around!!!! I highly recommend the Astor - I would stay there again and again...

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The Crowne Plaza was fabulous. Great location, good price and excellent service! We could not have been happier.

Reviews.Title: “positive”
Reviews.Author: David K
Reviews.Content: Great location, nice room, suprisingly found the housekeeping to be shoddy for this type of hotel. The parking is a joke as outlined below. This is compounded by lack of clarity as to to checkout procedure. We ended up paying cash at the garage (no formal receipt was given, informal after direct request). Staff was pleasant. Pool not as nice as Royal Sonesta which has outdoor bar service and better pool and sunning area.If it was close I would go with Royal Sonesta. I would return to this hotel if the rate was ok.

Reviews.Title: “A good deal, nice hotel”
Reviews.Author: Jockdoc
Reviews.Content: This was actually a very good deal for us. We booked 3 nights over the weekend for $83 each night. Three of us stayed in the room. It was right around the corner from ACME oysterhouse and we had blast. Right in the French Quarter, we walked daily to the French Market to eat and browse. The rooms were clean and actually fairly quiet. The fitness center could handle an update, especially the treadmills. The day we checked out, they were in the process of changing all the comforters and beddings. Checkout was simple. All in all a good stay for us.

HotelInfo.Name: Crowne Plaza Hotel Astor-New Orleans
HotelInfo.Address: 739 Canal Street at Bourbon, New Orleans, LA 70130
